metadata.case_name: Istimrardar of Kharwa v. Chief Commissioner of Ajmer

facts.text: The appellant is the Istimrardar of Kharwa. According to him, he has held a cattle fair on his estate every year for some twenty years.
It is admitted that the land on which the fair is normally held belongs to the appellant.
On 8-1-1951 the Chief Commissioner of Ajmer framed certain rules for the regulation of cattle and other fairs in the State of Ajmer under sections 40 and 41 of the Ajmer Laws Regulation of 1877.
One of the rules required that persons desiring to hold fairs should obtain a permit from the District Magistrate.
The appellant applied for a permit. This was refused on the ground that no more permits were to be issued to private individuals.
District Magistrate replied on application dated 9-7-1952: 'It has been decided that as a matter of policy permits to hold fairs will be issued only to local bodies and not to private individuals.'
The appellant applied under article 226 of the Constitution to the Judicial Commissioners Court at Ajmer for a writ directing authorities to permit holding the fair.
Judicial Commissioner refused writ but granted leave to appeal under article 132(1) on question of vires of Regulation and bye-laws, and allowed attack on District Magistrate's action.

legal_issues.text: Whether the rules framed by Chief Commissioner under sections 40 and 41 of Ajmer Laws Regulation 1877 are ultra vires.
Whether the rules amount to reasonable restriction on appellant's fundamental right under article 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g).
Validity of District Magistrate's refusal to grant permit.

petitioner_arguments.text: Fundamental rights under Constitution infringed; rules promulgated by Chief Commissioner ultra vires the Regulation.
Holding of annual fair is occupation or business within article 19(1)(g).

respondent_arguments.text: Permits to hold fairs issued only to local bodies and not to private individuals as a matter of policy.

court_reasoning.text: Rules travel beyond Regulation: empower District Magistrate to determine proper system of conservancy etc., which is delegation ultra vires as power is with Chief Commissioner.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Chief Commissioner cannot delegate authority to District Magistrate to make his own system.

court_reasoning.text: Fourth sub-rule empowers District Magistrate to revoke permit without reasons or notice: absolute arbitrary power ultra vires.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Regulation assumes right to hold fairs subject to rules on conservancy; cannot arbitrarily prohibit.

court_reasoning.text: District Magistrate's order prohibits fair without valid rules or law, hence bad. Covered by Tahir Hussain v. District Board.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Without aid of valid rules, no power to impose ban.

court_reasoning.text: Rules establish ad hoc control by DM via permits, not a system of conservancy/sanitation as required by s.40; not within rule-making power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Net effect is ad hoc control without constituting required system.

court_reasoning.text: DM not authorised to refuse on policy ground of issuing only to local bodies; rules only allow check on conservancy etc.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Impugned order bad on both grounds: exceeds rules and rules invalid.

holdings.text: Rules void to the extent they delegate to DM power to determine system of conservancy and arbitrary revocation power.
District Magistrate's order dated 18-9-1952 quashed as ultra vires.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tahir Hussain v. District Board, Muzaffarnagar
precedents_cited.relevance: Covers that without valid rules or law, authorities have no power to prohibit fairs.

statutes_cited.name: Ajmer Laws Regulation, 1877 (Reg. III of 1877)
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers Chief Commissioner to make rules on conservancy, sanitation, watch and ward, taxes, cattle registration, and penalties; rules exceed this scope.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental right to hold property and carry on business/occupation; restrictions must be reasonable; writ jurisdiction; appeal on constitutional question.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed, order of Judicial Commissioner set aside. Rules declared void to extent indicated, District Magistrate's order dated 18-9-1952 quashed. No order as to costs as point not raised timely.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that rules void in parts; quashing of refusal order.

key_quotes.text: "The Regulation assumes the right of persons to hold fairs, and all it requires is that those who do so should have due regard for the requirements of conservancy and sanitation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on scope of Regulation and right to hold fairs.

key_quotes.text: "Therefore, the Chief Commissioner cannot by Rule invest the District Magistrate with the right arbitrarily to prohibit that which the law and the Constitution not only allow, but guarantee."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains ultra vires nature of arbitrary power.

key_quotes.text: "It has been decided that as a matter of policy permits to hold fairs will be issued only to local bodies and not to private individuals."
key_quotes.speaker: district_magistrate
key_quotes.significance: Basis of refusal order held invalid.
